results.title: Orchestra rehearsal = Prova d'orchestra
results.creator_credit: Federico Fellini, Albatros Produktion and Radiotelevisione Italiana
results.brief_description: A television crew arrives to film the members of an orchestra rehearsing. The various musicians bicker and debate the merits of their individual contributions. Performing for the camera, they begin to challenge the authority of the conducter. As the situation turns chaotic and their rehearsal room begins to be demolished by a building crew, they all turn to the conductor for the restablishment of order. Maintaining a finely absurd comic tone throughout, “Orchestra Rehearsal” is a celebration of the meditative power of music and art. It is also a witty parable on the entropic contradictions that are threatening to tear modern Italy apart. With this short but elegant film, Fellini signalled a retreat from the lavish carnivalesque cinema he explored in the Sixties and Seventies. However, this does not mean this is not a suberbly directed work. In fact this was a return to form for Fellini, and his concern with the meaning and function of art in an increasingly alienated society is more expressively explored in “Orchestra Rehearsal” than it has been in any other film since “8 1/2”.

results.title: Loving our bottle
results.creator_credit: David Withers, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: ‘The Bottle’ in Rutherglen is a landmark that everyone in town has a connection to. Originally used as the town’s water tower, an iron mesh addition transformed it into the wine bottle of Rutherglen, a beacon by which locals find their way home.

results.title: From Latvia to Beechworth : personal journeys
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, Csilla Csongvay, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description: Beate and Marta immigrated to Australia with their families, changing their lives for ever. Leaving behind their native Latvia both women struggled with acceptance, a new language, new customs and a foreign environment. This film showcases the strength, humour and humanity needed to survive and to flourish in a new land. Inga, her mother Beate and their friend Marta reflect on their lives and traditions, old and new.

results.title: Orchestra!
results.creator_credit: Declan Lowney, Jonathan Hewes and Initial (GB)
results.brief_description: This series is an entertaining and informative introduction to the symphony orchestra. Featuring Maestro George Solti and the musical talent and humour of Dudley Moore, the three volumes trace the development of the various sections of the orchestra from the time of Bach and Handel to today. The theme of the four parts of the orchestra is established by breaking down a piece of music into its four constituent parts - strings, brass, percussion and woodwind.

The theme of the four parts of the orchestra is established by breaking down a piece of music into its four constituent parts - strings, brass, percussion and woodwind.

The theme of the four parts of the orchestra is established by breaking down a piece of music into its four constituent parts - strings, brass, percussion and woodwind.

results.title: The Making of 'Orchestra!': Piano. The conductor
results.creator_credit: Declan Lowney, Jonathan Lewes and Initial (GB)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Orchestra!”.
This volume of the “Orchestra!” series explores the making of the series. It examines the role of the piano as a solo instrument within an orchestra and the role of the conductor from learning the score through interpretation, the metronome and rehearsal technique.

results.title: Lower strings; Brass; Percussion
results.creator_credit: Declan Lowney, Jonathan Hewes and Initial (GB)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Orchestra!”.
This volume of the “Orchestra!” series examines the role of the lower strings: the cello and the double bass. Examines the effect of the invention of the valve on brass instruments and the role of percussion instruments in the orchestra.

results.title: Introduction to Orchestra!: Upper strings. Woodwind
results.creator_credit: Declan Lowney, Jonathan Hewes and Initial (GB)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Orchestra!”.
This volume of the “Orchestra!” series provides an introduction to the methods and objectives of the series. It also examines the role of the the upper string instruments, violin and viola and the early work of Bach and Handel. It also examines the woodwind section focussing on the oboe and the use of a double reed.

results.title: Opus: impressions of British art and culture
results.creator_credit: Don Levy, James Archibald and British Information Services
results.brief_description: An impressionistic survey of the arts in Britain ranging from sculptors and painters at work to a display of Mary Quant fashions and vistas of modern architecture. The theatre is represented by excerpts from three plays staged by the Royal Shakespeare Company and there is a sequence from a new ballet by Sir Frederick Ashton. Some of the work of Henry Moore is seen as well as paintings by Francis Bacon. Includes a brief appearance by a very young Googie Withers.
results.title_for_label: Opus: impressions of British art and culture
results.creator_credit_for_label: Don Levy, James Archibald and British Information Services

results.title: Options
results.creator_credit: Howard Sturges, Jerry Aronson and Perspective Films
results.brief_description: Believing that people want to feel, hear and become involved in art, the Chicago Museum of Contemporary Art, and its sister museums created “Options” - an exhibit meant to be touched and played with. It is a new approach to contemporary museums, involving more than just passive looking. The roving camera explores the reactions of the participants, and through the use of fast cuts, unusual angles and electronic music, the film becomes as involving an experience as the exhibit itself. Narrated by Ken Nordine.

results.title: Dartmouth
results.creator_credit: David Morgan, John Richardson and Kestrel Film Productions
results.brief_description: Dartmouth Dam, on the Mitta Mitta River in Victoria, has been designed to manage the waters of the River Murray for irrigation and urban needs. This film tells the story of the making of Dartmouth Dam including the study of plant and animal life. Reminiscences about the old Dartmouth township, and plans for the new town of Dartmouth. Narrated by Simon Chilvers.
